item.title: Ruth Mottram
item.description:
Most of the world‚Äôs population wants to fight climate change, but that majority thinks they are the minority.‚ÄùThis misperception matters. People are less likely to act for the common good if they think everyone else is free-riding" 69% of Europeans would be willing to give up 1% of their income each month to fight #ClimateChange üéÅ
How to do climate policy in the age of the green backlash - https://on.ft.com/3urWMxH via @FT

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description: I wish I could buy more groceries in glass jars or wrapped in brown paper. Both are recyclable or sustainable ‚Äì despite the world running out of sand https://news.northeastern.edu/2020/09/29/the-world-is-running-out-of-sand-the-second-most-exploited-resource-after-water/ glass is truly reusable and recyclable, and cellulose is supposedly sustainable and partially recyclable.Alas, supermarkets wrap everything in plastic.

item.title: Redish Lab
item.description: @tdverstynen @knutson_brain @neuralreckoning I really don't like the idea of a "living paper". I want a paper to be a stable isolated event in time that we can use as a solid brick in our construction of this scientific cathedral.We need to stop seeing a paper as the whole story. A paper is one small piece of the puzzle. We need to see the literature as the whole. (This is why we also need "theory papers" and "synthesis papers"*, because they integrate those bricks into new constructions we can use.)The reason the journal paper was invented in the first place (in the 1600s) was so that we could communicate part of the picture. Before that, people spent decades writing monographs, worrying about getting scooped, and they couldn't build on each other's work.A paper is a moment, a small discovery that other people should know about. It's the literature that is the living document we are building together.* I'm not fond of the term "review papers", "synthesis paper" would be a better term. A good review paper provides a new synthesis perspective and isn't just a list of the relevant papers to cite.

item.title: Das
item.description:
@computingnature @NicoleCRust
Horrible situation - for those who were cut out and also for the winners.
Good write up by Scalzi following the Barkley Sanford report

item.title: myrmepropagandist
item.description: Clad in rags, running through the jungle with my sisters. Nothing can stop us. We eat what we find. We fight each foe we face. We come in many sizes and we do not build houses or dig nests.At nightfall it is the bivouac. Our house is our bodies. Our house is a body. Sometimes I cradle a young one as I run. Sometimes I ride with mother ready to bite. The walls of our house can bite. The skin of our body has mandibles. We flow, the ant-birds singing of our coming. As an army, as one.

item.title: Dr. Lucky Tran :verified:
item.description: This something AI will never be able to recreate.‚ÄúKeith Haring died of AIDS aged 31 on 16 Feb 1990. His last piece of art, Unfinished Painting, was deliberately incomplete, reflecting the devastating, unquantifiable loss to the arts due to AIDS.‚Äù -Matthew Hodson

item.title: Dr. Lucky Tran :verified:
item.description: Los Angeles Times: "I‚Äôm an American doctor who went to Gaza. I have worked in other war zones. But what I witnessed in Gaza was not war ‚Äî it was annihilation.""I stopped keeping track of how many new orphans I had operated on. After surgery they would be filed somewhere in the hospital, I‚Äôm unsure of who will take care of them or how they will survive."https://www.latimes.com/opinion/story/2024-02-16/rafah-gaza-hospitals-surgery-israel-bombing-ground-offensive-children

item.title: Aure Free Press
item.description:
"Denmark has decided to send all its artillery to Ukraine"
- Mette Frederiksen, Prime Minister of Denmark."Ukraine is asking us for ammunition and artillery now. We, Denmark, have decided to transfer all our artillery to Ukraine. We have weapons, ammunition, air defense systems, which we do not use yet. They must be handed over to Ukraine."Thank you, Denmark! You are true friends of Freedom!
#AureFreePress #News #press #headline #Ukraine #denmark

item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: ‚ÄúFor me,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúthe secret sauce is always to make it personal. It‚Äôs always to find that intersection with my emotionality about the things that I‚Äôm talking about‚Ä¶‚Äù - Adam SavageI like this advice. For both scientific communication and teaching. Trying to engage an audience can sometimes feel like fumbling around in the dark-- but if you can turn yourself on, at least some of the audience will meet you halfway.This is from Holden Thorp's editorial here: https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.ado5736He interviewed Adam Savage here: https://www.science.org/content/blog-post/conversation-mythbusters-adam-savage

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: What exactly is a species? I take a look at polar bears, barn owls, frogs, giraffes, crustaceans, and more in my piece today in the New York Times. A simple answer is really hard to find! https://www.nytimes.com/2024/02/19/science/what-is-a-species.html

item.title: nature :press:
item.description: The decimal point is 150 years older than historians thoughtNature, Published online: 19 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00473-2Origin of the powerful calculation tool traced back to a mathematician from the Italian Renaissance. #presshttps://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-024-00473-2?utm_source=press.coop

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Another example of in-depth discussion, around a replication. It does show how difficult it is to separate work and self. But also how things do get clarified if people focus on the unclear or weak points of a piece of work, as they should.https://pubpeer.com/publications/62A8E2E7EC58EA6F22976510E3E456

item.title: Ramanujan
item.description:
Hi NeuroMatch! üëã We have a cool üö® new pre-print üö® out!
How do we make perceptual judgements about objects when many things in the background change across images?
We can tell just how many degrees Tucker is tilting his head even though the background is changing quite drastically. https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.02.14.580134v1

item.title: Mignon Fogarty
item.description:
Timeline of a project:1. Yes, I can absolutely do that 5 months from now.
2. I should get started soon.
3. I should *really* get started soon.
4. OMG! OK. Getting started.
5. I will never make this deadline.
6. I must change my name and start a new life in Genovia.
7. Work, work, work, work, work
8. I might actually make it.
9. That was easy!Repeat. (I am currently at Stage 8.)

item.title: Tilman
item.description:
This article by @garymarcus focuses on some specific aspects, like physical laws, but also goes. beyond and points out some more general aspects with these videos and where they may lead. Core points in screenshots üëáüèªhttps://garymarcus.substack.com/p/soras-surreal-physics

3/4
#verification

item.title: J√ºrgen
item.description: Spot-on‚Ä¶‚ÄúIf #hallucinations aren‚Äôt fixable, #generativeAI probably isn‚Äôt going to make a trillion dollars a year. And if it probably isn‚Äôt going to make a trillion dollars a year, it probably isn‚Äôt going to have the impact people seem to be expecting. And if it isn‚Äôt going to have that impact, maybe we should not be building our world around the premise that it is‚Äù @garymarcus #AIhttps://garymarcus.substack.com/p/what-if-generative-ai-turned-out
